diagnosis.score_summary: An anomaly in the dataset. eos has achieved near-total signal lock between the 'Controlled' website and the 'Wild' marketplace, creating a monolithic brand presence that is rare in CPG.

truth_1.headline: Medicine vs. Maintenance
truth_1.gap_description: WWW signals 'Restoration' (Healing Damage). PDP signals 'Hydration' (Daily Maintenance). You are selling a repair kit on your site and a maintenance fluid on Amazon.
truth_1.why_matters: The user with damaged skin will trust the website but doubt the Amazon listing. By softening the claim on Amazon to 'Maintenance,' you lose the urgency of the 'Repair' buyer.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are caught between being a doctor and a spa therapist. The data demands a decision: either commit to the 'Healer' claim on Amazon to capture the high-need problem skin market (Option A), or soften the website to 'Maintenance' to align with the mass-market reality of daily lotion (Option B). You cannot cure people on one channel and just lube them up on the other.

truth_2.headline: The Badge vs. The Mob
truth_2.gap_description: WWW relies on 'Certifiers' (Allure/Badges) to prove worth. PDP relies on 'The Fans' (54k Reviews). The website appeals to authority; the marketplace appeals to the crowd.
truth_2.evidence: Validator Slider: WWW 'Certifiers' (3/5) vs. PDP 'The Fans' (5/5)
truth_2.why_matters: Institutional authority (Allure) is fading; Crowd authority (TikTok/Amazon) is rising. The website feels like a dusty trophy cabinet compared to the riotous approval of the Amazon page.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are fighting a war of credibility with two different weapons. The choice is clear: either pivot the website to highlight the 'Viral Mob' as the primary source of truth (Option A), or keep relying on 'Industry Badges' to maintain a facade of prestige (Option B). In the modern era, 54,000 strangers are louder than one magazine editor.

truth_3.headline: Clean vs. Fun
truth_3.gap_description: On WWW, 'The Innocent' (Clean) is the secondary archetype. On PDP, 'The Jester' (Fun) takes that slot. The website is slightly more puritanical; the marketplace is ready to party.
truth_3.why_matters: This subtle drift creates a 'Personality Dampener' on the direct site. Users coming from a viral TikTok (Jester energy) land on a site talking about safety (Innocent energy) and feel the buzz die.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: Your website is the responsible older sibling, while your Amazon listing is the life of the party. You must choose: either loosen the tie on the website to match the viral energy of the product (Option A), or discipline the Amazon listing to prioritize 'Safety' over 'Vibes' (Option B). A brand cannot be 'Safe' and 'Wild' in the same breath without confusing the audience.

truth_4.headline: The Comfort Trap
truth_4.gap_description: WWW aims for 'Comfort' (2/5). PDP deepens this to 'Sanctuary' (1/5). The Amazon experience promises a deeper emotional withdrawal from the world than the website does.
truth_4.why_matters: It is dangerous to promise 'Sanctuary' (total safety) on a third-party platform you don't control. If the delivery fails or the box is crushed, the 'Sanctuary' promise is broken more violently than a simple 'Comfort' promise.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: You are promising a spiritual retreat (Sanctuary) on a logistics platform (Amazon). The risk is high. You must decide: either elevate the website experience to truly own the 'Sanctuary' narrative where you control the unboxing (Option A), or downgrade the Amazon promise to simple 'Comfort' to manage expectations (Option B). Deep emotion requires deep control.

truth_5.headline: The King Pretending to be a Prince
truth_5.gap_description: Both channels match on 'The Trend-Setter.' But PDP proves it with '#1 Best Seller' stats, while WWW just claims it with aesthetics. The proof is stronger than the claim.
truth_5.evidence: Social Proof: PDP Real Data (#1 Rank) > WWW Aesthetic Claims
truth_5.why_matters: The website is acting like it's *trying* to be cool. The Amazon page proves it *is* cool. The DTC site is under-leveraging the sheer dominance of the sales volume.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your website is humble-bragging, but your Amazon sales are screaming dominance. The opportunity is to stop 'signaling' relevance and start 'displaying' dominance. You must choose: either import the raw, aggressive sales data to the homepage to bully the competition (Option A), or keep the website as a polite 'Brand Home' that ignores the commercial reality (Option B). Kings do not whisper.

marker_1.so_what: This is a strategic lock. Both channels agree that the authority comes from the plant (Bio-Active), not the patent. The brand successfully resists the temptation to 'science-wash' itself on Amazon.

marker_2.so_what: Perfect alignment on accessibility. The brand does not try to artificially elevate its status on the website; it proudly owns its mass-market 'Democratic' nature across the board. This builds massive trust.

marker_3.so_what: The 'Do No Harm' signal is broadcast without interference. Whether browsing the site or the shelf, the customer hears the same promise: effectiveness will never come at the cost of irritation.

marker_4.so_what: The 'Masstige' balance is held perfectly tight. The visuals say 'Premium' (4/5) while the price signals 'Staple' (3/5). This tension is the engine of the brand's success, and it is replicated flawlessly.

marker_5.so_what: The brand has successfully dismantled the corporate wall. By maintaining 'The BFF' dynamic on both channels, they create a peer-to-peer relationship that feels immune to corporate skepticism.

marker_6.so_what: The primary 'Lover' signal is strong, but the secondary flavor shifts. The website tries to be 'Good' (Innocent), while Amazon tries to be 'Fun' (Jester). It creates a slight personality wobble between 'Pure' and 'Playful.'

marker_7.so_what: Total vocal synchronization. The brand speaks 'Internet' fluently on every platform. It uses slang and high energy without sounding like a corporate imposter, which is a high-difficulty achievement.

marker_8.so_what: The 'Dopamine' aesthetic is unbreakable. Whether in a controlled web environment or the rigid Amazon grid, the brand forces its 'Playful' physics (swirls/cream) through the screen. A masterclass in visual consistency.

marker_9.so_what: The persuasion logic is identical: hook them with the ingredient (Shea), but close them with the dream (Cashmere). The brand refuses to become a dry textbook on either channel.

marker_10.so_what: The story setting is firmly planted in the 'Harvest.' Even without a founder face (The Nobel), the brand generates character through its ingredients. It feels like a product of nature, not a boardroom.

marker_11.so_what: A shift in validation authority. The website leans on the 'Allure' badge (Old World), while Amazon leans on the 'Review Count' (New World). It's not a break, but it shows where the real power lies.

marker_12.so_what: The brand has successfully monopolized the word 'Shea' in the consumer's mind. By repeating this single USP across every touchpoint, they block competitors from claiming the same mental real estate.

marker_13.so_what: The content strategy is pure 'Pitch.' Neither channel wastes time on deep education; both exist to stimulate desire through high-end editorial visuals. The brand knows it is selling a vibe, not a science project.

marker_14.so_what: The diagnostic break. The website promises to 'Heal' you (Restoration), while Amazon promises to 'Maintain' you (Hydration). This confuses the high-need customer who is looking for a solution to damage.

marker_15.so_what: A near-perfect match in emotional payoff. Both channels sell 'Delight,' but Amazon pushes it slightly deeper into 'Sanctuary.' It's a consistent promise of emotional withdrawal from a stressful world.

marker_16.so_what: The brand successfully frames a $10 lotion as a 'Statement' piece. By leveraging the '#vanillagirl' trend on both channels, they convert a commodity purchase into a signal of cultural relevance.

marker_17.so_what: The herd instinct is fully activated. Both channels signal 'The Majority' choice, reassuring the buyer that they are making the same safe, approved decision as millions of others.
